15.text: I’m on the Guyanese Massif between Venezuela and Brazil, in the largest remaining virgin jungle we have left.

21.text: One hour on the Canaracuni River takes me to meet the Sanema people, a nomadic offshoot of the Yanomamis.

32.text: When the game is exhausted here, the Sanema move on to other areas where they find more “animal company”.

43.text: Their houses have walls of mud or poles and they’re topped off with palm leaves.

48.text: They dig a fire pit in the middle.

52.text: The men are hunters while the women garden and gather wild plantain and manioc.

60.text: Manioc is a huge meaty tuber.

62.text: Once it’s dug up they wash it and grate it with a very clever invention:

66.text: the remains of a DC-9 fuselage that crashed in the river years ago.

82.text: Once the manioc is grated they put it in a flexible basket called a seucan in order to extract all of its bitter juice,

89.text: which contains the highly poisonous hydrocyanic acid.

107.text: Now the tapioca is ready to be used in making a bread called cazabe that’s eaten in this part of the jungle.

126.text: It’s hard to admit, but we’re all addicted to something...

132.text: The Sanema are addicted to tobacco, but in the form of leaves and ashes mashed together.

137.text: The mineral salts in this delectable paste make it useful as a dietary supplement.

142.text: This startling look is the result of having stuffed a wad of the paste between the lower lip and gum.

150.text: These young Yecuanas are preparing their blowpipes for the hunt.

154.text: They splinter the trunks of palm trees and roll cotton around one end of each shaft to make small darts.

164.text: They wet the cotton with the sap of the tunare tree,

167.text: which contains a poison so strong that it can kill a man before the cock crows thrice.

174.text: And if the cock doesn’t crow, the young hunters will take care of him anyway.

178.text: They’re experts at imitating birdsong either alone or with the help of their handmade whistles…

187.text: That’s how they manage to attract their prey, to deceive them

190.text: and to take care of them with a poison dart without a second thought.

194.text: Horrified at the poisonous spectacle, I decide to hit the road.

208.text: And I land at the mouth of the Ebro, the mightiest river on the Iberian Peninsula.

213.text: This is an ideal spot for European migratory birds to take a break along their lengthy journey.

220.text: There’s a wide variety of ecosystems on the delta, and this is where our heroes the flamingos like to stop for a rest.

241.text: The only places in Europe where the flamingos regularly raise their young are the Camargue in France

247.text: and the Fuente de Piedra Lagoon in Spain.

256.text: The Ebro Delta is a pleasant spot where they can spend some down time along the way.

270.text: It takes time and pigment to develop their characteristic adult plumage.

293.text: Their unusually rosy appearance is neither permanent nor inherent to the species.

297.text: They acquire it from microorganisms in their food that contain natural pigments.

313.text: Without those microorganisms “the bloom would be off the rose”

317.text: and they would inevitably revert to a pale shadow of their splendour

324.text: From the look of things these leggy birds don’t skimp when it comes to hygiene

333.text: The truth is I’m surprised by their meticulous bathing habits.

357.text: They are born neither pink nor long-necked.

360.text: As chicks they have “normal” necks but they grow rapidly in adolescence and their necks stretch out to an amazing length.

369.text: Rested and refreshed, the flamingos continue on their way

387.text: this time to find a group of people so tied to the water that they can’t imagine any other kind of life.

407.text: The Bajau live on the waters of the Gulf of Tomini off the island of Sulawesi.

416.text: These nomads have lived on the sea for centuries.

422.text: They live on these small boats called leppas.

424.text: They’re born on them, they grow up on them,

427.text: they marry and have children on them… and they die on them.

432.text: Their relationship to the sea is so close that they’re unhappy to step on land,

436.text: where they really do feel like fish out of water.

439.text: If they leave the leppa, it’s only to visit the underwater depths.

445.text: They can dive to a depth of up to 50 feet and stay under water for a full five minutes.

457.text: And they always bring home a souvenir after an underwater excursion.

475.text: We still don’t know how the Bajau came to live here or how they came to this way of life.

480.text: Some anthropologists say that they fled from inter-tribal violence in Malaysia, but they believe otherwise.

488.text: They say that they went to sea in search of their lost princess.

491.text: It seems that a storm took her by surprise whilst she was bathing and dragged her to sea as far as Sulawesi.

497.text: The Bajau came after her and when they found her they decided to stay.

520.text: They rarely venture far from shore, though.

522.text: They stay close by, fishing in the coral reefs. What more could anyone ask?

531.text: In the evening the Bajau bring their boats close to the mangrove swamp for protection.

544.text: They meet all their needs on these houseboats made of api wood,

547.text: but there is so little room to move that older people’s legs actually atrophy!

559.text: Even so, up to five people can live on the boats, which have bedrooms, pantries, kitchens and living rooms.

569.text: Between the leppas and the airplane, I can’t feel my legs either.

572.text: Lucky me, though; where I’m going next there’s more than enough room to stretch them out.

584.text: Amboseli Park occupies an area of almost 150 square miles.

589.text: Located very close to Kilimanjaro, it has unusual weather patterns and a fantastic orphanage for young elephants.

597.text: The elephant herds come out into the open after the rains.

600.text: Almost 700 individual elephants have been counted here.

605.text: Staying cool is crucial to them, and since animal’s bodies are designed to meet their needs,

609.text: they have numerous blood vessels in their huge fan-like ears.

612.text: Just by moving them once in a while they can cool a lot of blood.

623.text: Elephants have always been protected here.

625.text: The Masai keep poachers away, and the Department of Wildlife keeps an eye on the herds.

633.text: Baby elephants can get sunburned during their first six weeks of life, especially their ears.

639.text: That's why they flock to the mud baths. A healthy coating of mud and sand helps protect them.

703.text: It’s not easy to feed these babies.

706.text: For the first three months after they’re born, the orphans get baby bottles of coconut oil as often as they want, night and day.

711.text: Coconut oil happens to be very similar to elephant milk.

730.text: When they’re a little bit older, they begin to be fed vegetable matter combined with milk.

734.text: This is at about nine months.

737.text: However, they won't be entirely weaned until they’re four or five years old.

746.text: That’s when the young elephants are ready to live in their natural habitat.

753.text: I fly away and back again like the star of the show at our next stop: the boomerang.

775.text: Ever since people began to hunt, they've racked their brains to invent ever more efficient weapons to bring down their prey

781.text: But some of them came up with solutions before the others…

801.text: Deep in the rainforest they cut lengths of flexible bougainvillea to make spears and harpoons for fishing.

812.text: They took up the spear against the white men who invaded their country and made them prisoners in their own land.

822.text: Back outside the forest, a fire is built and the flexible new shafts are heated for straightening and hardening.

843.text: Back outside the forest, a fire is built and the flexible new shafts are heated for straightening and hardening.

857.text: When the tide goes out they hunt the dangerous sting rays.

860.text: These rays can hide in the sand and give you a painful, stinging surprise… but this hunter is watchful and attentive.

874.text: After capturing the animal, he holds its tail in his mouth and pulls out the poisonous stinger.

883.text: Sometimes, of course, a spear can be a little too short

888.text: That’s why they invented the boomerang.

894.text: A simple piece of wood formed into a slight curve that makes it more accurate when thrown.

905.text: The heavier it is, the more crushing is the blow when it hits its prey.

914.text: The most skilled hunters can hit an animal from a distance of more than 175 yards.

924.text: Yes, yes, 175 yards. Don’t look at me like that.

933.text: And contrary to popular belief, the boomerang doesn’t come back after it's thrown.

937.text: That story was made up for tourists, my friend.

942.text: I do fly back though to meet an animal that would gladly swallow the boomerang as an appetizer.

953.text: I’m back in Cuba’s mangrove swamps, a mysterious world of light and shadow

958.text: where a mixture of salt and fresh water is fed by ocean tides and river estuaries.

963.text: All sorts of creatures are to be found

984.text: Of course given his impressive dimensions our protagonist is sure to be found.

997.text: A voracious manatee combs the area for nourishment, propelled by its enormous fin.

1002.text: Just 10 % of its body weight in food will satisfy its hunger.

1006.text: Of course we’re talking about a mere 150 pounds of food a day.

1010.text: No worry, that’s just about 200 heads of lettuce.

1017.text: A group of fish escorts the manatee, since everywhere it goes it stirs up the seabed

1030.text: This also helps keep the canals free of vegetation.

1033.text: Of course it's better not to get in the manatee’s way

1071.text: These peaceful creatures live underwater but periodically come up to breathe.

1080.text: Legend has it that Christopher Columbus sighted them in 1492,

1084.text: and in his astonishment he confused them with the mermaids described by Herodotus.

1093.text: Mermaids indeed, genuine mermaids… well no, I guess not.

1123.text: And from here we go to terra firme to visit the aristocratic macaques of Borneo

1139.text: I’m in the tropical rainforest on the island of Borneo.

1142.text: It’s very primitive and over 150 million years old, which is saying something.

1148.text: Until recently, these huge trees called dipterocarpos populated the second largest jungle in the world,

1155.text: surpassed in size only by the Amazon basin.

1159.text: Ninety percent of the photosynthesis on the planet takes place in forests like this

1163.text: and 31 species of primates live in this lush habitat.

1167.text: Twenty three of them can be found only here.

1171.text: This macaque looking at me in surprise is of a variety called “pigtail”.

1176.text: Pigs or not, there’s no question that these primates are fabulously social.

1181.text: They live in clans of up to 40 individuals with very hierarchical ranking and a genuine aristocracy that’s very much in charge.

1197.text: Their status ranking is handed down from parents to children.

1201.text: It can change, but the individual would have to earn merit

1204.text: One way to win favour with the chief is to clean and groom his coat

1210.text: Females spend their whole lives right where they were born.

1212.text: Males, on the other hand, will go to other families to mate.

1218.text: Mothers from traditionally powerful families care for their heirs very lovingly

1232.text: and take them for play dates with children of other “good families”

1235.text: Some day these youngsters may work together in a governing coalition.

1271.text: xThe macaques have a lot in common with us, so much that hundreds of them die every year

1276.text: in cruel laboratory experiments testing medicines or cosmetics that we value.

1281.text: We are the real beasts of the story

1313.text: It seems to be cooling off. I’m on my way.
